abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Agricultural Extension II Project. The
            Bank's preparation and appraisal of this project was
            satisfactory. The project was justified and a strong effort
            was made to reflect the best of past experience in project
            design. Borrower commitment to this project was steadily
            eroded by fiscal and economic problems and political
            factors, over which individual federal and state project
            agencies had little control. The project exceeded federal
            and state fiscal and institutional capacity during a
            difficult transitional period in Brazil. This could not have
            been foreseen at appraisal, although the Bank appreciated
            the fact that relative state/regional implementation
            capacity was not uniform. The lessons from this project are
            the following: (a) When a project strategy and/or design is
            overtaken by political, legal or economic events, the Bank
            should promptly undertake the needed changes; (b)
            Macroeconomic, fiscal and political conditions are critical
            arbiters of project outcome, influencing Borrower
            commitment, counterpart funding availability, project
            incentives and the behavior of institutions; (c) Projects of
            national scope should ensure that: supervision quality can
            be maintained; required actions are flexibly tailored to
            regional/state capacity and conditions; and,
            poorly-performing states/regions receive concentrated
            attention and possibly special incentives to improve
            performance; (d) Effective M&E integrated into the daily
            work of extensionists and extension institutions, and fed
            into impact and cost-effectiveness analyses, remains a
            challenge for the National System for Technical Assistance
            and Rural Extension (SIBRATER); (e) Institutional
            strengthening should be supported by and coalesce around a
            strategic vision of national (and state-level) extension
            services; and (f) The project validated the Bank's
            policy of not financing salaries.
